Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Application of fluorescence spectroscopy for the characterization of dissolved organic matter: Disentangling common misconceptions and underlying chemistry

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration: Dissolved organic matter (DOM) is a complex mixture of carbon containing molecules that are present in all aquatic environments. DOM plays an important role in aquatic ecosystems. Thus, variations in DOM chemical composition may inform understanding of different processes in the environment. Fluorescence has emerged as a common tool to characterize DOM, but many challenges are associated with its use. In this research collaboration between the University of Colorado at Boulder and Montana State University, the connection between fluorescence characterization of DOM and specific chemical constituents within this mixture will be evaluated. The results from this study will impact the field of environmental engineering and aquatic science by providing specific guidelines and education regarding the use of fluorescence as a broad metric for DOM chemical understanding in aquatic ecosystems. <br/> <br/>The characterization of dissolved organic matter (DOM) by fluorescence spectroscopy has become ubiquitous in the environmental engineering and science communities. Specifically, the use of excitation emission matrices (EEMs) has emerged as one of the most common tools used by researchers examining DOM on numerous natural and engineered processes. Given the amount of data collected in an EEM, several qualitative and quantitative approaches have been developed to analyze the results. In most cases, these approaches attempt to tie a fluorescence response to a chemical constituent or behavior within DOM. The environmental engineering and science community has embraced fluorescence as an important tool for the characterization of DOM. However, little progress has been made in understanding what specific factors (e.g., chemical structures and molecular composition) controls the observed fluorescence response. The main goal of this project is to fill the deficiencies in chemical interpretations of fluorescence information by conducting a detailed evaluation of fluorescence analyses as a broad measure to interpret the chemical composition and variability of DOM. The results from this proposal will offer guidelines to engineers and scientists regarding the use of fluorescence for the characterization of DOM. The use of different commonly used fluorescent interpretation metrics will be calibrated against distinct chemical analyses of DOM samples from highly fluorescing environmental fractions. It is expected that this project will provide the community with detailed guidelines regarding the limitations of the use of fluorescence for DOM research in natural and engineered systems. The educational component will focus on the incorporation of results from this study into collegiate curricula and departmental seminars at the collaborating institutions. Graduate and undergraduate students will be educated in analytical chemistry techniques routinely used for water quality assessments. They will also learn advanced analytical DOM characterization techniques at the molecular level. The fluorescent community will be informed of the results from this work via convened sessions organized at domestic and international scientific conferences and publications in high impact scientific journals.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The use of analytical chemistry techniques to characterize carbon-based organic molecules in aquatic and terrestrial ecosystems is an essential component of understanding how carbon is produced, used, and recycled on Earth. Specifically, fluorescence spectroscopy has become crucial for advancing carbon cycling research in environmental engineering and natural aquatic and terrestrial science communities. This technique is rapid and offers a wealth of data from small sample volumes (< 5 mL), providing information on organic molecule origin and reactivity. As a group, these molecules represent an essential pool of carbon worldwide known as dissolved organic matter (DOM). DOM is largest group of reactive carbon-based materials on Earth; therefore, it is essential to learn about where it comes from and what it is going to do. While the vast application of fluorescence spectroscopy continues to grow, so do the challenges with interpretation. Therefore, it is important that researchers know the underlying chemistries responsible for the data they collect. To date, this has been a major challenge to resolve in the engineering and natural science communities. The main objective of our work was to fill deficiencies in chemical interpretations of DOM from fluorescence spectroscopy data using multiple analytical chemistry techniques.

Our investigation involved four techniques to identify what drives DOM fluorescence behavior. We built an in-line multi-detector system to separate DOM molecules into various groups by their molecular weights and then successively measure small, medium, and large molecular weight carbon concentrations, absorbance properties, and fluorescence properties. Our team conducted experiments on standards commonly used in the DOM and engineering community and found which molecular weight fractions contain fluorescent DOM, providing more detail than is detected by using fluorescence spectroscopy alone. We also applied this system to characterize samples collected from a freshwater creek in Boulder, Colorado, USA, upstream and downstream of a waste-water treatment plant. Effluent DOM is commonly analyzed by fluorescence spectroscopy; therefore, these samples represent real-life examples of how to gain more information on carbon cycling and DOM changes with human influences. We identified anthropogenic imprints as changes in DOM concentration and fluorescence that the engineering community can use to decipher ecosystem health downstream of other treatment plants.

Lastly, the system was designed to collect individual fractions along the microscopic molecular weight continuum for further off-line analysis using more advanced analytical chemistry techniques that probe molecular composition and structure. This was an essential step to advance chemical interpretations of DOM fluorescence and further understanding of anthropogenic imprints at the molecular level, beyond weight fractions, e.g., DOM structural bonds, how many carbon, hydrogen, oxygen, nitrogen, and sulfur atoms make up the DOM mixtures we collect from aquatic and terrestrial environments. In essence, the novel coupling of multiple instruments and its fraction collection capabilities for future off-line analyses provided a new method to reduce common misconceptions and interpretations occurring in the fluorescent environmental science and engineering communities. Our products unify interpretation barriers across both communities and open the doors to new opportunities for young and established researchers. From that point of view, our results better inform educators and ecosystem and treatment plant managers about how to track human-driven changes in ecosystems right outside our backdoors.

We communicated guidelines and provided education regarding the use of fluorescence for DOM chemical understanding in aquatic ecosystems that will greatly impact the environmental engineering and aquatic science fields. We published six peer-reviewed scientific articles in environmental science, technology, and aquatic science journals accessible to researchers and the general public addressing what challenges the fluorescence and DOM characterization communities have faced, how to resolve such issues, how our novel system works, and what future applications our system may be used for. Currently, we have three more publications in the queue to be submitted for publication or are under review. Our group spanned across researchers at various career stages including undergraduate and graduate students, postdoctoral researchers in their early career stages, and mid-to-senior level professors. Also, the team brought expertise in engineering, chemistry, physics, and environmental science disciplines, which was essential for the project?s success and broadened the way in which each of us think about carbon cycling locally, regionally, and globally, as well as with human impacts. This information has been disseminated into multiple courses across the project investigator?s courses at the undergraduate and graduate level. In addition, the students, postdocs, and professors have communicated the results in oral presentations at major chemical, environmental science, and engineering conferences in the USA as well as at other academic institutions in the US as internationally. To achieve lasting impacts in the STEM communities, we developed creative and diverse formats to disseminate our findings including audio, visual, written, and artistic products. We shared these products  both virtually and in-person with broad audiences, provided mechanisms for professional training for young researchers, and educated students interested in pursuing future careers in STEM.
